conclusion: Analyze how shadows A, B, C, and D change as the light source moves forward above the objects.
Object near A is a gray sphere/dome.
Object near B is a blue cylindrical alarm clock with metal accents.
Object near C is a pink/red circular pastry/cookie.
Object near D is a square waffle or wafer with some filling.
When a light source moves closer to objects, shadows become smaller and move closer to being directly beneath their objects.
Shadow A will become smaller and move closer to being directly under the sphere when the light moves forward.
Shadow B will become more compact and shift to be more directly beneath the clock when the light moves forward.
Shadow C will become smaller and move to be more directly beneath the pastry when the light moves forward.
Shadow D will become smaller and move to be more directly beneath the waffle when the light moves forward.
When a light source is high above objects, shadows are cast at an angle and appear larger than the objects.
As the light source moves closer while remaining above, the angle of light rays becomes more vertical, causing shadows to shrink and move closer to their objects.
Final answer: Shadows A, B, C, and D will become smaller, move directly beneath their objects, decrease distance from objects, and have sharper edges.
